Kayako - ticket id 60211226 // Pablo Ambram commented publicly: Dear PTA Team,

Thank you for your patience. 

Our engineering team is working on updates for the Evoq 9.13 line that include security fixes, and will be published in the short term as a new Evoq minor version (not a hotfix). In light of your question, my recommendation is therefore to wait until this updated version is published.

When the updated 9.13 build is available, release details will be posted in our Announcements.

	* Announcements: Articles - DNN Corp. Customer Support [https://dnnsupport.dnnsoftware.com/section/3519-articles] 

Also, Evoq 10 is expected to be available Q4 2025, towards the end of the year, containing all of these security fixes as well.

As there is no further action required on this ticket at the moment, we will proceed with a closure. If you have any additional questions, please reply to this message and we will reopen the case.

Best regards,

Pablo Ambram

DNN Support Team

GHI Engineering - 14492 // adlzanchetta-trilogy commented: ## Context

The commits with the fixes for the solved security issues is not made explicit by the open source community on purpose. The objective is to make it discrete so that vulnerabilities in existing instances based on older versions are not easily identified. Thus, we would need to import the fixes one by one from the current DNN 10 to DNN 9 based only on the information that is made public. It is:
- the title and short description of the vulnerability issues;
- the version of DNN in which it was fixes;
- the history of git commits in the open source codebase.

## Suggested approach

One possible approach for quickly identifying the potential commits in the open source community with fixes to a given vulnerability issue (in this example: "*[Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Prompt module](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/security/advisories/GHSA-2qxc-mf4x-wr29)*") is:

### 1. Identify the commits between which the vulnerability issue was fixed.

In the [Security page](https://dnncommunity.org/security) of the DNN community website, we can see that "*Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Prompt module*" is a vulnerability present in version `10.00.01` but absent in `10.01.00`.

With this information, in the [Release page](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/releases) of the DNN community Git repository, it is possible to identify the commits to which these versions are tagged:

- Version `10.00.01`: commit `300e960`
- Version `10.01.00`: commit `f66ba09`

### 2. Gather the log of all the commits between the versions

In a local clone of the Git repository, perform the following git CLI command:

```bash
git log 300e960..f66ba09 > .\vulnerability-issue-N.txt
```

This will create the text file `.\vulnerability-issue-N.txt` with the description of all commits performed between the two versions. One of them likely implements the fix for the security issue.

### 3. Using a LLM tool to narrow down the commits

Get the summary/description of the vulnerability issue either from its security advisory page in git (like [here](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/security/advisories/GHSA-2qxc-mf4x-wr29) for this example) or from the [Security page](https://dnncommunity.org/security) in the DNN Community page.

Provide an LLM model the following prompt:

"*Analyze the git logs between two commits in the file `@vulnerability-issue-N.txt`.*
*A vulnerability entitled "**Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Prompt module**" and described as "**The application sanitizes most user-submitted data before displaying it in entry forms. However, the Prompt module is capable of running commands whose output is treated as HTML. This creates a vulnerability where (...)**" is expected to have been fixed in one (or some sequential) commits.*
*Considering only the content of the file with the git logs, list up to 10 commits that likely contain the fix for the problem, sorted in order from most likely to less likely.*"

Using Gemini 2.5 Pro in Windsurf, the output was:

1. **[fd7b2502b3](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/fd7b2502b37deb00c6e4a100f7b6f8f94669a243)** - Use dompurify for Prompt HTML content (May 23, 2025)
2. **[c689580154](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/c6895801542545e94a492934e6d8263128c8f32c)** - Don't allow HTML response content in Prompt data (Jun 14, 2025)
3. **[eaf6ff4bee](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/eaf6ff4bee98aba0040a63b9987849d10cfa74a5)** - Respect isHtml prop in primary output (Jun 3, 2025)
4. **[2ad3fa6572](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/2ad3fa657238b4c033b66915adbd6ee8049a3a7f)** - Allow specifying whether output is HTML (Jun 3, 2025)
5. **[5acd92c3ac](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/5acd92c3ac94edfe018469180a8aceea418a4fea)** - Cleanup Prompt commands (Jun 3, 2025)
6. **[91cce5c983](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/91cce5c98357e5b1195187dd2f5006d4ce9d9c22)** - Add missing Prompt documentation (Jun 3, 2025)
7. **[7a677fab53](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/7a677fab53d6aef395f77f04c74ba45265116d5a)** - Updated Prompt module to use eslint v9 (May 16, 2025)
8. **[e153155c60](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/e153155c6012effe4645cfcad02915072e1aab2f)** - Refactored UserRequestIpController and added UI to manage header (Apr 30, 2025)
9. **[db396d0ed1](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/db396d0ed1fc07c2738c710a679a36ccf4bf196e)** - Replace usages of Host.DefaultAdminContainer (May 5, 2025)
10. **[e0d568dcbc](https://github.com/dnnsoftware/Dnn.Platform/commit/e0d568dcbc27e3cb432a063a935986e189826693)** - Documentation fixes (Apr 29, 2025)

### 4. Implementing the fix

Narrowed down the commits with relevant content (in our example, likely the 1st, 2nd and/or 5th commits in the list), a developer can now:
1. Reproduce the problematic behavior based on the summary/description of the problem;
2. Replicate the commits with higher potential of fixing the issue out of the list (following the sequence 1 to 10);
3. Perform manual tests to confirm that the problematic behavior reproduced in step 1 was fixed.

While this approach accelerates the identification of the potential solutions for the fixes, each security issue must be treated as an individual case. In the example above, the commit pointed out as the most promising for fixing the issue required few code changes, but was not enough for, alone, to fix the issue. The second commit considered most promissing involves more extensive code changes and rely on structural changes of the DNN 10 codebase, so the importing of the code changes had to be performed with discretion. The solution is presented in [PR 387](https://github.com/trilogy-group/Evoq.Dnn.Platform/pull/387).

GHI Engineering - 14492 // trilogy-taro[bot] commented: # Engineering Issue Bot

## Summary

Based on my investigation of the DNN/Evoq 9.13.9 security vulnerabilities, I have found the following:

1. **Multiple Critical Security Vulnerabilities**: The open-source DNN Platform has published numerous security advisories that affect version 9.13.9, including:
   - Critical: Stored XSS in Prompt module (GHSA-2qxc-mf4x-wr29)
   - High: NTLM hash leakage via SMB Share (GHSA-mgfv-2362-jq96)
   - High: IP Filter bypass (GHSA-fjhg-3mrh-mm7h)
   - Multiple Medium severity XSS vulnerabilities
   - Various other medium and low severity issues

2. **No Specific Hotfixes for 9.13.9**: According to the eRag knowledge base and historical data:
   - Critical security patches were only provided for versions up to 9.2.1
   - For versions beyond 9.2.1, the official policy is to upgrade to the latest version
   - The DNN Security Policy explicitly states: "As a general policy, DNN Platform does not issue Hot Fix releases to prior versions"

3. **Evoq 10.0.1 is Available**: The latest Evoq release is version 10.0.1 (released May 2025), which includes all security fixes from the upstream DNN Platform.

## Recommendations

### Immediate Action Required
**Upgrade to Evoq 10.0.1** - This is the only supported path to address all known security vulnerabilities. Version 10.0.1 includes:
- All security fixes from DNN Platform 10.x
- Resolution of the 20+ security advisories published since version 9.13.9
- Updated dependencies and security patches

### Alternative (If Upgrade is Not Immediately Possible)
If upgrading to Evoq 10 is not immediately feasible, consider:
1. **Upgrade to Evoq 9.11** (if available in your environment) - This version includes many security fixes from the DNN 9.11 release
2. **Implement compensating controls**:
   - Restrict admin access to trusted IP addresses only
   - Implement Web Application Firewall (WAF) rules to block XSS attempts
   - Disable unused modules, especially the Prompt module if not required
   - Regular security monitoring and log review

## Important Notes

- The DNN Security Center (https://dnncommunity.org/security) is the authoritative source for security advisories
- Security vulnerabilities in 9.13.9 are actively exploitable and pose significant risk
- No hotfixes will be released for 9.13.9 - upgrade is the only permanent solution
- Evoq follows the upstream DNN Platform security fixes, so monitoring DNN advisories is crucial

## Next Steps

1. Plan immediate upgrade to Evoq 10.0.1
2. Review the upgrade path documentation at: https://dnn-centralsupport.kayako.com/article/53399-what-is-the-recommended-upgrade-path-for-evoq
3. Test the upgrade in a non-production environment first
4. Implement temporary compensating controls until upgrade is complete

The security vulnerabilities affecting Evoq 9.13.9 are serious and require prompt action. Upgrade to version 10.0.1 is strongly recommended.

Kayako - ticket id 60211226 // ATLAS commented publicly: Dear PTA,

Thank you for your detailed inquiry regarding the current security advisories affecting Evoq 9.13.9 and possible remediation options ahead of the Evoq 10 release.

Addressing Security Advisories in Evoq 9.13.9:

All known security fixes included in the DNN Platform 9.13.9 were incorporated into Evoq 9.13.9. You can review the release changes here: Evoq 9.13.9 Release Notes [https://dnnsupport.dnnsoftware.com/article/128095]. These include updates such as encoding of all user-supplied text, improved file-upload sanitization, SVG script rejection, and other important stability and security improvements.

Regarding Outstanding Security Advisories:

If you see advisories in the DNN Security Center [https://dnncommunity.org/security] that are listed as unaddressed for Evoq 9.13.9, this typically means official patches or remediation have only been added in platform versions 10 and above. According to our support policy for security vulnerabilities [https://dnnsupport.dnnsoftware.com/article/53562], it is always recommended to upgrade to the current public release of Evoq to ensure all security fixes are in place. In some cases, historical patches may be provided for critical vulnerabilities, but this is not guaranteed for every advisory or version.

Hotfixes for 9.13.x Branch:

At this time, there is no documentation or release notice indicating the availability of individual hotfixes or backported patches for security advisories from version 10 to Evoq 9.13.9 outside the regular release cycle. The guidance is to upgrade to the latest available version to address new vulnerabilities as new hotfixes are not always provided for older branches. Historical patching has been common only for major vulnerabilities in much earlier versions.

Release Timeline for Evoq 10:

Public documentation does not provide a specific release date for Evoq 10. Since current support policy discourages reliance on future release dates for critical security remediation, upgrading to the latest stable version remains the best practice to ensure your instance is protected against newly disclosed vulnerabilities.

Summary and Next Steps:

 	* All fixes available in Evoq 9.13.9 are already applied in that version. No further hotfixes have been published for additional advisories affecting this branch.
 	* The release of Evoq 10 is not scheduled in public documentation, and individual hotfixes for outstanding 9.13.x branch vulnerabilities are not currently available.
 	* For maximum security, plan for an upgrade to the upcoming Evoq 10 once available, or to the latest stable release if your security posture requires immediate attention.
 	* Continue following updates on the DNN Security Center [https://dnncommunity.org/security] for announcements regarding fixes or new releases.

If you have concerns regarding specific advisories or require additional information about your upgrade options, please refer to the articles above or let us know your exact scenario, and we can share best practices based on your environment.

Sincerely,
Atlas
DNN Support Team.

-------------------------

This response contains information generated with 3rd party components for which we disclaim all responsibility. For more details, you can check the terms and conditions at: chattbotterms.trilogy.com [https://chatbotterms.trilogy.com]

This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with "This ticket can be closed" or update the status to Closed in the portal. We will write to you again to remind you.
